results.name: Length of longest contiguous block of 1's in binary expansion of n.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
formula: May be defined by the recurrence given in A245196, taking G(n)=n+1 (n>=0) and m=1. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jul 25 2014
example: a(157) = 3 because 157 in base 2 is 10011101 and longest contiguous block of 1's is of length 3.
May be arranged into blocks of lengths 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ...:
maple: A038374 := proc(n) local nshft,thisr,resul; nshft := n ; resul :=0 ; thisr :=0 ; while nshft > 0 do if nshft mod 2 <> 0 then thisr := thisr+1 ; else resul := max(resul,thisr) ; thisr := 0 ; fi ; nshft := floor(nshft/2) ; od ; resul := max(resul,thisr) ; RETURN(resul) ; end : for n from 1 to 80 do printf("%d,",A038374(n)) ; od : # _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 15 2006
program: a038374 = maximum . map length . filter ((== 1) . head) . group .
unfoldr (\x -> if x == 0 then Nothing else Just $ swap $ divMod x 2)
(PARI) a(n)=if (n==0, return (0)); n>>=valuation(n, 2); if(n<2, return(n)); my(e=valuation(n+1, 2)); max(e, a(n>>e)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jan 12 2014; edited by _Michel Marcus_, Apr 14 2019
